Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: A Novel Strategy for Large-Scale Industrial Topology Optimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to develop a novel and powerful topology optimization method. The research will be carried through close collaboration with Mercury Marine (WI), the industrial partner for this award. The specific tasks are: (1) to identify a set of topology optimization problems that are representative of the challenges faced by the industry today; (2) to significantly improve the speed and reliability of topology optimization; (3) to focus on product realization and commercialization. In addition to collaborating with the industrial partner, the research will leverage student-designed SAE Formula cars at UW-Madison to put the topology optimization algorithms to a rigorous test.

If successful, the research will provide a fresh stimulus to the mathematically rich discipline of topology optimization. It will further strengthen the theory of topological sensitivity by applying it to complex problems of engineering interest. It will explore and exploit relationship between existing topology optimization methods and new method. Through industrial interaction, the research will create better understanding, formulation and solution of practical topology optimization problems. The broader impacts of the research are: (1) better optimization techniques will lead to reduced physical prototyping, and reduced material usage; (2) undergraduates and graduate students at UW-Madison will be exposed to topology optimization through case-studies, and summer co-ops at Mercury-Marine, and (3) the impact of the industrial interaction is on budding engineers who will be exposed to a unique blend of research, industrial experience and formal education. The research is transformative in that it suggests a fundamentally new direction for topology optimization that has not been investigated by the research community.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit
The intellectual outcomes of this study are that: (1) large scale topology optimization poses theoretical and practical challenges, and (2) these can be solved through careful attention to both the underlying finite element analysis and optimization algorithm. 
During the process of addressing these challenges, we uncovered a novel finite element framework, namely, assembly-free deflated finite element analysis, and a novel topology optimization algorithm, called Pareto. Creating and implementing these two discoveries is one the major outcomes of the research. Through this implementation, we were able to solve problems that could not be addressed before.

Intellectually, we now have a better understanding of large scale topology optimization, and its relationship to engineering design. The proposed framework will help researchers and engineers discover new and creative designs, primarily in field of structural analysis.


Broader Impact:
The broader outcome of this study was in the training of two graduate (PhD) students. The students explored the interplay between topology optimization and finite element analysis. The assembly-free deflation method and Pareto optimization algorithm, that resulted from this study were discovered during their graduate study. The technology was transferred to Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation, and is currently being commercialized by a start-up company.

Numerous publications have resulted from this research, and their dissemination has helped reached engineers from all over the world. Software plugins was developed for SolidWorks, a popular CAD/CAE packages such as SolidWorks. This has ben used by over 500+ universities and companies around the world.


Some of the critical research findings have been incorporated into a senior graduate level course (ME 748) at the University of Wisconsin, Madison.
